text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
internet's busiest music nerd and it is
time for a review of this new arkham
kick won this is the latest collection
of songs from producer sound designer
songwriter vocalist arca highly
anticipated album for me because this
record marks a huge era of change for
the venezuelan native since the first
leg of the 2010s Arcas music has shown
incredible promise
for example the insane displays of wonky
glitch and experimental hip hop
production on her early stretch EPS then
immediately becoming the secret weapon
of Kanye West having a hand in multiple
tracks from his record yeezus from their
providing the entire backdrop to LP 1
the debut full-length album of all R&B
alchemist fka twigs the production on
that project still Wow's me to this day
let's also not forget her work with
Bjork and Colella in the coming years as
well and all while this was happening
ARCA was developing her own sound with a
series of deeply experimental solo
records none of which really hit for me
consistently but still the sound design
especially on Zen and especially on
mutant was particularly bold on Arcos
self-titled record in 2017 we began to
see an eerie and dystopian blend of
ambien art and Glitch pop take hold
vocals also becoming more of a focal
point leading to some strangely
beautiful and almost operatic highlights
like sin rumba or anoche but oddly all
of that feels eons ago when thinking
about how ARCA presents herself today we
had the announcement of her non-binary
identity her putting herself out there
more in the promotional material in the
music videos ARCA is like an entirely
new artist at this point so going into
this record it was like the slate had
just been wiped clean for me like my
expectations had just dropped or that
was until I began to hear some of the
teaser tracks which for me were a mixed
bag there is non-binary which is a track
I'm not surprised ended up the intro of
this thing lyrically it does read like a
statement of intent or a confrontational
statement of self also encouraging
others to
do the same in their own way the most
surprising thing about this track being
ARCA gently and somewhat charismatic
leer a poveri primal instrumental some
of the vocals and lyricism here are weak
sure but the most confusing thing about
this track is that after all this time
ARCA still doesn't seem that intent on
structuring things and tying things up
in her songs effectively there is a
dramatic intro and build up on this
track a hard-hitting refrain a bridge
and then it just sort of trails off into
nothing the following time I would argue
has an even lower impact with a lot of
layered Spacey and new-age synth
passages disembodied vocals - all of
which comes together like a build up
that never really builds up too much of
anything the following mycket Rafi isn't
even shorter listen but it's visceral
nature makes it so much more impressive
in my view this track is a piece of
dynamic nuanced punchy and glitchy
reggaeton whose production is just
insane the details in this track are
just mind-boggling ARCA could have done
an entire record of songs in this vein
and it would have sufficed especially
with that dark bassy transition at the
midpoint of the song it sounds like just
IDM and Flying Lotus from another planet
we also have que lo que featuring
Rosalia stylized as que el que and
exciting crossover with one of the most
talented singers out there right now
with ARCA essentially using Rosalia's
voice in the mix here manipulating it
just treating it like an instrument like
anything else here while still
maintaining the beautiful and unique
qualities of her singing loving the
glitches and the grooves on this track -
it is a futuristic Latin pop banger in
so many ways this track is as
over-the-top as possible in the best way
possible the dizzying vocal treatments
the rigid somewhat industrial ish synth
lead those awesome rhythmic and vocal
breakdowns and in in the guns reloading
everywhere so these were the teasers to
the record I loved a couple the other
two not as much in the end the tracklist
on this thing ends up being a bit of a
potpourri of bangers and Drifters
songs and moments that essentially trail
off or don't really climax in a
gratifying way despite maybe having a
really cool idea or two in the mix
whether that be the manic singing and
rapping intense electronics all over the
track or a key key which really could
have used another passage a build-up a
transition something to break up the
monotony of this one singular idea
outside of a very ungratified ending
then the song afterwards with Bjork
kicks off as a very wondrous chilling
beautiful vocal piece the instrumental
pairs perfectly with her voice which is
not surprising considering their work in
the past vocally the song trades off to
ARCA whose singing is not nearly as
strong but really what ends up making
the song feel pretty underwhelming is
that from that point it just slowly
trails downward into nothing there's no
other offerings or passages beyond this
point other than just slowly deflating
this record thankfully is a little back
loaded there is a stronger showing in
the tracklist on the second half in my
view there is the disorienting rager
watch featuring shy girl the bass II
groove and speedy little rap flows and
melting passages of synthesizers and
vocals are all ear candy for the insane
there is also the booming and demented
rip the slit and ARCA flexes her insane
IDM and deconstructed production muscles
once again on Shiki featuring sophie
where much of the track is painted by
these very quickly repeating Manero
Manero Manero Manero Manero Manero
Manero Manero Manero mono but even
faster than that it's like just a voice
stuck in my head ah driving me to the
brink behind that these aggressive
punchy rhythms and then suddenly
transitioning into these haunting
dramatic passages of vocals and droning
synth tones it's such a roller coaster
it is sensory overload
it is emotional overload it's so
gratifying and so confusing at the same
time the records final moments I thought
were just okay there is the song Makoti
which is a somewhat hazy dreamy heavily
layered trap inspired piece that
doesn't hit too hard it's kind of breezy
over and done with before you even
realize it's going on then there is the
closer no que de nada which is a
stripped back ballad that features Arcas
voice over a very simple and dramatic
art pop instrumental very Bjork inspired
not blown away by it but it is one of
the most fleshed out songs in the
tracklist - so can't fault it too much
overall I thought this record was kind
of flawed but still it managed to be my
favorite arca album so far best material
on any project I've heard up until this
point loved the crossovers love the
experiments loved the boldness there are
some duds and there are some lulls in
the tracklist sure but this project is
still a great showing and I hope just
the start of a new exciting era for arca
feeling a decent too strong 7 on this
one transition have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
